The Related Discourses

8. Not Knowing (3)

Thus have I heard:1 One time, the Buddha stayed in the kingdom of Śrāvastī at Anāthapiṇḍada Park in Jeta Grove.

It was then that the Bhagavān addressed the monks, “When you don’t know and understand form, don’t become free of desire for it, and your mind isn’t liberated, you aren’t able to end your suffering. Thus, when you don’t know and understand sensation, perception, volition, and consciousness, don’t become free of desire for them, and your mind isn’t liberated, you aren’t able to end your suffering.

“Monks, if you know and understand form, if you become free of desire for it, and your mind is liberated, you’ll be able to end your suffering. Thus, if you know and understand sensation, perception, volition, and consciousness, if you become free of desire for them, and your mind is liberated, you’ll be able to [1c] end your suffering.”

The monks who heard what the Buddha had taught then rejoiced and handed it down.

Endnotes

  1. This sutra is parallel to SN 22.24 and SA 2.8. The Taisho version of this sutra copies the content of SA 1.10 into the beginning, turning it into a “double sutra." I’ve followed Yinshun’s suggestion to delete this material as spurious on the grounds that the uddana for this group of sutras only mentions one sutra on delight. We should also note that SA 2.8 would be a strong parallel if we delete the added material, which then maintains the pattern of SA 1.1-10 corresponding to SA 2.1-10.
Translator: Charles Patton
